3444913251.resolved_title: Psychological ‘Specialness Spirals’ Can Make Ordinary Items Feel Like Treasures
3444913251.excerpt: Have you ever bought an item and then just not gotten around to using it because the time never felt right? Researchers now have the data for what they call ”nonconsumption”—and it may explain how clutter accumulates.

1.caption: The longer you hold off on using an everyday purchase, the more likely you are to preserve it untouched. Photo by Ekaterina Kapranova/Getty Images

2.caption: When is the right time to make the first marks in a fresh new notebook? Grace Cary/Moment via Getty Images

3.caption: Postponing use seems to change an item’s humble origin story. Francis Dean/Corbis Historical via Getty Images

3750782297.resolved_title: Why Do We Love the Music We Love?
3750782297.excerpt: If you’ve ever made a playlist—for yourself or someone else—you’ve done the delicate dance of music curation. By what logic did you order the songs? What nearly made it on, but got left out, and why?

2.caption: Rogers and Ogas’ new book, out now.

1354154109.excerpt: In July 2014, Alexis Madrigal reported for NPR on the strange case of Pinterest.

4.caption: Pinterest’s value proposition is drawn verbatim from their logged-out Search page. Evernote’s is drawn verbatim from their logged-out homepage, but is one sentence among many; here, I focus on the “Collect” aspect of Evernote’s functionality, rather than its many other use cases. Pinboard’s is drawn verbatim from their logged-out homepage. Product Hunt’s is a paraphrased version of the longer purpose statement on their About page: “Product Hunt surfaces the best new products, every day. It’s a place for product-loving enthusiasts to share and geek out about the latest mobile apps, websites, hardware projects, and tech creations.” Pocket’s is a paraphrased version of their mission statement, drawn from this June 2015 post by CEO Nate Weiner: “To enable people to save the most interesting and important content flowing through their day so they can view it anytime, anywhere.” Instapaper’s is drawn verbatim from their logged-out homepage; only capitalization has been adjusted. Wunderlist’s is drawn from this March 2013 blog post introducing the “Add to Wunderlist” feature; admittedly, it doesn’t fully describe Wunderlist’s overall value proposition, but I’ve highlighted it here to improve comparability. Tumblr’s is a paraphrased version of the value proposition outlined on their About page: “Tumblr lets you effortlessly share anything.”

2177185177.excerpt: The limitations of algorithmic curation of news and culture has prompted a return to the use of actual humans to select, edit, and explain. Who knows, this might spread to another less traditional media: apps.

3330236956.excerpt: Personalizing fashion at scale requires that we build an inventory whose size and complexity are as great as that of our client base.

3647706050.resolved_title: Lifelong Quests! Lawsuits! Feuds! A Super-Serious Story About Cereal.

3857410172.resolved_title: Thrift shops thrive when disorder is balanced with high seller knowledge
3857410172.excerpt: Shoppers looking to “pop some tags” may be drawn to disordered thrift shop displays because they signal hidden treasure in their inventory.

3626543315.resolved_title: The Obsessive World of Digital Music Collectors
3626543315.excerpt: Almost everyone I know who has ever kept a collection of digital music—that is, a folder full of music files on a hard drive—can point to a specific extinction-level event in their life that decimated their carefully curated library to the point of no return.

3668554288.resolved_title: The Dynamics of Exploration on Spotify
3668554288.excerpt: “Variety is the spice of life”, as the saying attributed to poet William Cowper goes. People crave heterogeneity and avoid boredom across all aspects of their online experiences.

3785834526.excerpt: Who has their hand on the dial? Talk with someone who works at Apple, Amazon, Google, Linkedin, Facebook, etc, and they’ll be happy to give you tips on how to work the platform to your advantage. How to get a bit more attention for your podcast or your website or your photos…

3900717810.given_title: The Secretive, Delightful Man Changing Everything We Know About Theme Parks
3900717810.excerpt: Kevin Perjurer, the pseudonymous creator of the wildly popular YouTube channel Defunctland, made it to Disney World just twice in his youth. On the final day of the first vacation, he purchased a souvenir book detailing the many attractions that had been paved over as the park grew.

3493130362.excerpt: I know, we're all doing vinyl and there has probably been no better time to be a vinyl junkie, given the number of places selling it and the resurgent and vibrant second hand market.

962775900.excerpt: The only song that matters as much as the song you’re listening to right now is the one that follows this. Picture this: you’re in a special moment…and the next song comes on…BZZZZZ Buzzkill! It probably happened because it was programmed by an algorithm alone.

1.caption: Both search results and the news feed are algorithmically driven

3.caption: Curation makes sense in the middle of Google and Facebook: some personalization, and a finite set of data to curate

963948530.excerpt: Personalization algorithms influence what you’ve chosen yesterday, what you choose today and what you’ll be choosing tomorrow. Simultaneously, there seems to be something wrong with personalization. We are continuously bumping into obtrusive, uninteresting ads.

3727009034.given_title: The French Art of Cheese-Label Collecting
3727009034.resolved_title: The French Art of Cheese-Label Collecting
3727009034.excerpt: Tyrosemiophilia is a mouthful to pronounce. Breaking it down, the meaning is still murky: in ancient Greek, tyro means cheese, semio is sign or label, and philos is love. The term does not refer to savoring rich, creamy cheese.

1.caption: Cheese labels are immensely charming. Courtesy Serge Schéhadé

2.caption: Bucolic scenes of countryside life are common label themes. Courtesy Serge Schéhadé

3.caption: Figures from Saint George to Napoleon adorn many labels. Courtesy Serge Schéhadé

4.caption: Serge Schéhadé has thousands of labels carefully preserved in binders. Anna Mindess

1939378229.excerpt: In 1983, Nach Waxman sought to stock his new bookstore, Kitchen Arts & Letters, with curiosities that weren’t cookbooks. He soon discovered Victorian-era advertisements known as trade cards. “I thought it would be a really interesting item to have in the store,” he says.

3333182037.resolved_title: The man who hunts 'hidden' radioactive objects

Kripke was 76, and she had been collecting dictionaries, and books about dictionaries, most of her life, almost since her parents gave her Webster’s Collegiate when she was 10.

2365334917.given_title: Sword Swallowers and Shrunken Heads: An Ode to Johnny Fox and His Freakator
2365334917.resolved_title: Sword Swallowers and Shrunken Heads: An Ode to Johnny Fox and His Freakatorium
2365334917.excerpt: Walking home down Clinton Street in Manhattan’s Lower East Side one day in 1999, writer and filmmaker Laurie Gwen Shapiro encountered a tall, dark, and handsome man on the sidewalk swallowing fire.

1.caption: This huge ’60s sideshow banner—roughly 8 by 9.5 feet—was painted by esteemed circus artist Fred Johnson to promote the so-called Human Volcano.

2.caption: Johnny Fox performing a sword-swallowing routine at the Maryland Renaissance Fair in 2007.

3.caption: Cabinet cards and trophies adorned Johnny Fox’s New York City museum, Freakatorium: El Museo Loco, which was open from 1999 to 2005.

4.caption: A mid-20th-century Tantric Himalayan Buddhist ritual Kapala skull, or a human skull decorated with semi-precious stones, glass eyes, and Tibetan silver work.

5.caption: A “boudoir card” of the Sacred Hairy Family of Burma, two of whom had hypertrichosis and were exhibited by P.T. Barnum in England for one season, and for a short tour in the United States, in 1888.

6.caption: A diminutive overnight trunk owned by Tom Thumb and his wife, Lavinia, circa 1870, as exhibited at the Freakatorium Museum. Items within the trunk include two of Lavinia’s unmatched gloves as well as one high black shoe, a Tom Thumb-owned leather glove, his top hat, a partial deck of miniature playing cards, Lavinia’s copy of the play “All Tangled Up,” and a hand-colored CDV of Tom and Lavinia Thumb and their child.

7.caption: Johnny Fox’s “Cracker Shooting” Helmet. The volunteer may have donned this helmet, which allowed Fox to place a cracker in the slot on top. Then Fox would swallow a loaded gun and proceed to shoot the cracker off the volunteer’s head. The repurposed WWI helmet was used by Fox for his version of the stunt made famous by Kar-Mi

2919198943.resolved_title: Fun Delivered: World's Foremost Experts on Whoopee Cushions and Silly Putty Tell All
2919198943.excerpt: Farts are funny. Always have been; always will be. In fact, flatulence humor goes back to the first known joke, recorded by ancient Sumerians. Since then, it’s lingered for thousands of years, wafting from Medieval illuminated devotionals to Shakespeare’s plays.

1.caption: Stan and Mardi Timm show off Johnson Smith novelties they’ve collected. Stan wears X-Ray Spex and holds a Tark Electric Razor. Mardi wears a sailor’s hat that says “Kiss Me Honey I Won’t Bite” and holds a Little Gem Lung Tester and Bust Developer.

2.caption: An original JEM Rubber Whoopee Cushion from the 1930s, first sold in the Johnson Smith & Co. catalog. It’s one of seven farting pillows in the Timms’ collection.

3.caption: A 1974 Johnson Smith Company catalog sold black-light posters, boxing puppets, and volcano kits.

4.caption: The Tark Electric Razor was first introduced as a new, exciting invention in the 1930s.

5.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
5.caption: “For Dirty Old Men,” a 1973 gag box by H. Fishlove & Co.

6.caption: This vintage Doggie Doodit pile of fake poop is a classic prank.

7.caption: Stan Timm doing magic with his daughter Steffane in the ’80s when she was 3 years old.

8.caption: These 1954 Fake Cigarette Burn stickers, by H. Fishlove & Co., were designed to upset a housewife who was emotionally invested in keeping the furniture nice.

9.caption: A 1979 Fascinating Ant Farm, by Uncle Milton Toys, is just one of the half-dozen vintage ant farms in the Timms’ collection.

10.caption: How handy would a Handi-Mike from the 1930s be?

11.caption: A vintage Snake Bow Tie, for all the times you’ve wanted a snake to pop out of your neck.

12.caption: A Johnson Smith catalog entry for Itching Powder, a popular way to torment your friends and frenemies in the ’20s.

13.caption: In the 1930s and 1940s, a Johnson Smith customer could order a live turtle that would arrive in a box featuring Pinocchio on the cover, licensed by Walt Disney Enterprises to H. Fishlove & Co.

14.caption: A page of wild animals offered in the Johnson Smith catalog while it was in Racine

15.caption: This entry from the 1938 Johnson Smith & Co. catalog depicts the sort of mean pranks kids could presumably play by throwing their voices with The Ventrilo.

16.caption: This 1933 guide, Book of Great Secrets: Valuable Money Making Recipes, spoke to the deepest desires of Johnson Smith customers suffering in the Great Depression.

17.caption: The title of this 1946 Johnson Smith guide really says it all, Secrets of Black Art: The Devil’s Legacy to Earth’s Mortals, or The Sciences of Magic, Witchcraft, Alchemy, Demonology, Omens, Mesmerism, Necromancy, Etc.

18.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
18.caption: The Timms have two copies of Clog Dancing Made Easy, one from 1910 and one from 1923, so apparently the fad lasted more than a decade.

19.caption: Young boys and men were susceptible to guides promising to make them at least appear bigger and stronger, like How to Perform Strong Man Stunts.

20.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
20.caption: The Little Webster Dictionary is one of many miniature books Johnson Smith and other novelty companies produced.

21.caption: Vintage stink bombs made in Germany and sold by Johnson Smith.

22.caption: Revenge of the nerds, indeed—a vintage H. Fishlove catalog.

23.caption: “9th Hole Kit for Emergencies,” a 1967 gag box by H. Fishlove & Co., features a miniature chamber pot and toilet-paper roll. This is one of 76 toilet novelties in the Timms’ collection

24.caption: Chattering Teeth were a British knockoff of the Yakity-Yak Talking Teeth, which were introduced by H. Fishlove & Co. in 1950. The Timms’ have 56 items that jitter, thanks to spring-driven motors.

25.caption: Stan Timm demonstrates a Super Comb while wearing Hollywood Super Specs, both by H. Fishlove & Co. The Timms have 19 oversize objects.

26.caption: This 1956 hula girl Mystery Dancer, produced by H. Fishlove & Co., used a small Alnico

27.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
27.caption: A vintage snake prank in a Cloeman’s English Mustard container.

28.caption: A 1938 Johnson Smith catalog entry for “Harmless Indoor Fireworks.”

29.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
29.caption: A typical Dribble Glass by S.S. Adams.

30.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
30.caption: This vintage prank package of Chesterfield Cigarettes holds a pop-up that reads, “chiseler,” an early 20th-century term for “cheater” or “swindler.”

31.caption: This 1950 H. Fishlove & Co. “girlie” gag box plays on America’s breast-obsessed culture.

32.caption: Tingle came in a bottle that was the shape of a headless, armless, and legless woman. H. Fishlove & Co first sold this “simulated after-shave lotion” gag gift in 1951, and later applied to patent it in 1977.

33.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
33.caption: Joke books mocking Irish immigrants were popular in America from the 1900s to the 1920s.

34.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
34.caption: This vintage German-made sand card, “On the Pot,” reveals where a night of hard drinking could lead you.

35.caption: This Stereokazoo promises to play “doubly loud.”

36.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
36.caption: Doozie Funny Animal Faces, made by Kenner in 1960, is one of the strangest toys in the Timms’ collection.

37.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
37.caption: This 1930s version of the standard glasses-and-nose disguise is made of high-quality material. It once belonged to a clown in the Hagenbeck-Wallace Circus based in Peru, Indiana.

38.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
38.caption: These ESP Cards were developed in Duke University’s Parapsychology Laboratory by Karl Zener and Joseph Banks Rhine in the 1930s. In “Ghostbusters,” Dr. Venkman “experiments” with them at Columbia University.

39.credit: Courtesy of Stan and Mardi Timm
39.caption: Takitapart is a mechanical puzzle from 1939 with a penny inside.

40.credit: Courtesy of Mardi and Stan Timm
40.caption: This Ink Bottle and Ink Spot prank has a spill made of cardboard, not metal like earlier versions, so it’s probably from World War II, when metal was rationed.

3767343718.given_title: Why Hot Wheels are one of the most inflation-proof toys in American history
3767343718.resolved_title: Why Hot Wheels are one of the most inflation-proof toys in American history
3767343718.excerpt: Inflation, the curse of our pocketbooks and the Federal Reserve, has hit almost every good in the U.S. But the price of a beloved toy has managed to hover around $1 — for more than 50 years. Hot Wheels are a retail oddity.

3610092128.excerpt: One of the perks of being Jimmy Carter’s grandson is that you get to attend the family’s annual trip, a gathering for the whole extended Carter clan that’s organized by the former President and First Lady.
